Description: Blue glazed composition shabti of Sety I: the lower leg section is lost. With details painted in black (probably manganese dioxide), Sety I is shown wealing the striped royal 'nemes' headcloth, once equipped with a rearing cobra above his brow, a broad collar that imitates glazed composition beads, and bracelets that also would have been of glazed composition. In each hand he holds a hoe, and from over his proper left shoulder hangs a rectangular grain bag - agricultural instruments recalling the function of such shabtis as servants for manual labour in the Beyond. The tasks are enumerated in the carefully drawn bands of text drawn from Chapter 6 of the 'Book of the Dead'. Though mould-made, details of the facial features, hoes, and grain bag were probably added with a sharp tool before firing, a general practice that accounts for the variation of features in mould-made shabtis.The lack of glaze in the devices suggests the piece was self-glazed.
Findspot: Found/Acquired: Biban el-Muluk (Valley of the Kings - Thebes), KV17
Curator's comments: Bibliography: E. T. Whyte, “Some Remarks on the Sepulchral Figures usually called Ushabti”, in ‘Proceedings of the Society of Biblical Archaeology’ 18, no. 134 (London, April 1896) pp. 144-45, pl. V; E. A. Wallis Budge 'A Guide to the Fourth, Fifth and Sixth Egyptian Rooms, and the Coptic Room' (London, 1922), p. 142.
Bibliographic references: Friedman 1998 / Gifts of the Nile: Ancient Egyptian Faience (48)
